title: 105_s1642
content:
The Act is titled the "Federal Financial Assistance Management Improvement Act of 1998". The Congress acknowledges the complexity of delivering services through over 600 Federal financial assistance programs, recognizing the need to streamline administrative requirements to improve cost-effective service delivery at the local level. Private, nonprofit organizations are facing complex problems that require coordinating various services. Streamlining Federal financial assistance procedures will enhance service delivery to the public. The Act aims to improve Federal financial assistance programs by simplifying application and reporting requirements, enhancing service delivery to the public, and promoting coordination among service providers. In this Act, the term "Director" refers to the Director of the Office of Management and Budget, "Federal agency" means any agency defined under section 551(1) of title 5, United States Code, and "Federal financial assistance" has the same meaning as defined in section 7501(a)(5) of title 31, United States Code. Federal financial assistance is provided to a non-Federal entity, which includes State, local government, or nonprofit organizations. Local government is defined as a political subdivision of a State. Nonprofit organization refers to any organization operated primarily for scientific purposes. An organization is defined as a non-profit entity operated for public interest, using proceeds to maintain its operations. "State" refers to any State of the United States or its territories. The term "tribal government" refers to an Indian tribe as defined in section 7501(a)(9) of title 31, United States Code. The term "uniform administrative rule" means a government-wide uniform rule. The term "uniform administrative rule" refers to a government-wide uniform rule for generally applicable requirements across multiple Federal financial assistance programs. SEC. 5. DUTIES OF FEDERAL AGENCIES. Federal agencies must develop and implement a plan within 18 months of this Act's enactment. The plan should streamline procedures for financial assistance programs, participate in interagency processes, use a common application system, and designate a lead agency official. The Act requires federal agencies to designate a lead official, allow electronic applications for funds, ensure timely and high-quality reporting, and set annual goals for performance measurement. The Act mandates federal agencies to designate a lead official, allow electronic fund applications, ensure timely reporting, and set annual performance goals. Noncompliant agencies must report reasons for noncompliance to the Senate and House committees, with the Director having the authority to extend the plan development and implementation period for up to 12 months after consultation. After consultation with committees, the Director may extend the plan development period for noncompliant agencies for up to 12 months. Each agency must publish their plan in the Federal Register for public comment and hold public forums on the plan. Each Federal agency must hold public forums on the plan and consult with non-Federal entities during development. The plan developed under subsection (a) must be submitted to the Director and Congress, with annual reports on its implementation and performance. The agency must report annually to the Director and Congress on the implementation of the plan and its performance in meeting specified goals and objectives. This report can be included in general management reports required by law. SEC. 6. DUTIES OF THE DIRECTOR. The Director, in consultation with agency heads and representatives of non-Federal entities, shall direct, coordinate, and assist Federal agencies in establishing a common application and reporting system for Federal financial assistance programs. This system includes a common application for multiple programs serving similar purposes and administered by different agencies. The Director, in consultation with agency heads and representatives of non-Federal entities, shall establish a common system for applying, managing, and reporting on funding from multiple Federal financial assistance programs. This system will have uniform administrative rules across different Federal agencies. An interagency process will address coordination issues. The interagency process aims to streamline and simplify administrative procedures and reporting requirements for Federal financial assistance programs, improve coordination of information sharing, and ensure compliance with the Privacy Act of 1974. The Director may designate a lead agency and use interagency working groups to improve the timeliness, completeness, and quality of information received by Federal agencies from recipients of Federal financial assistance. Agencies are required to submit plans and reports for review. The Director may use interagency working groups to assist in carrying out responsibilities. Agencies must submit information and reports for review. The Director has the authority to exempt agencies from the Act's requirements if they do not have many financial assistance programs. Exempted agencies will be listed on OMB's website. SEC. 7. EVALUATION. The Director shall contract with the National Academy of Public Administration to evaluate the effectiveness of the Act. The evaluation, to be submitted within 4 years, will assess the Act's effectiveness and provide recommendations for further implementation. The Director will assess the Act's effectiveness and make recommendations for further implementation, evaluate agency performance, and assess coordination among various entities in implementing the Act. SEC. 8. COLLECTION OF INFORMATION.

Director or Federal agency can gather information for review of financial integrity or quality of services of activities assisted by Federal financial assistance.

SEC. 9. JUDICIAL REVIEW.

No judicial review of compliance with Act provisions. Act does not create enforceable rights through administrative or judicial action.

SEC. 10. STATUTORY REQUIREMENTS. SEC. 10. STATUTORY REQUIREMENTS.

This Act does not deviate from statutory requirements for Federal financial assistance programs.

SEC. 11. EFFECTIVE DATE AND SUNSET.

The Act will be effective upon enactment and will expire five years later.
